elements.content: This work systematically investigates an exemplary mixed-matrix membrane (MMM) system composed of a UiO-66-NH2 metal–organic framework (MOF) and a 6FDA-Durene polyimide. The UiO-66-NH2 MOF is post-synthetically modified with 6FDA-Durene oligomers through either chemical or thermal imidization routes. The thermal­(T)-PSM approach does not require reactive small molecules for synthesis, thereby allowing the cross-linking reaction between the MOF and the polymer to occur only on the MOF surface. Conversely, the chemical­(C)-PSM approach requires reactive small molecules for synthesis, thereby altering internal amine functionality of UiO-66-NH2. Upon embedding these PSM-MOFs in high molecular weight 6FDA-Durene polymers, CO2 and CH4 pure-gas permeation tests reveal that the T-PSM-MOF has synergistic improvements in both permeability and selectivity due to enhanced interfacial compatibility without significant modification to the internal MOF framework. Conversely, MMMs formed with the C-PSM-MOF experienced a significant decrease in permeability due to reactions that occurred inside of the MOF pore structure. These findings suggest that there is a critical need to consider reaction conditions and their corresponding effect on MOF structures when pursuing a PSM approach to form MMMs with desired performance enhancements.
elements.clean_text:
This work systematically
investigates an exemplary mixed-matrix
membrane (MMM) system composed of a UiO-66-NH2 metal–organic
framework (MOF) and a 6FDA-Durene polyimide. The UiO-66-NH2 MOF is post-synthetically modified with 6FDA-Durene oligomers through
either chemical or thermal imidization routes. The thermal­(T)-PSM
approach does not require reactive small molecules for synthesis,
thereby allowing the cross-linking reaction between the MOF and the
polymer to occur only on the MOF surface. Conversely, the chemical­(C)-PSM
approach requires reactive small molecules for synthesis, thereby
altering internal amine functionality of UiO-66-NH2. Upon
embedding these PSM-MOFs in high molecular weight 6FDA-Durene polymers,
CO2 and CH4 pure-gas permeation tests reveal
that the T-PSM-MOF has synergistic improvements in both permeability
and selectivity due to enhanced interfacial compatibility without
significant modification to the internal MOF framework. Conversely,
MMMs formed with the C-PSM-MOF experienced a significant decrease
in permeability due to reactions that occurred inside of the MOF pore
structure. These findings suggest that there is a critical need to
consider reaction conditions and their corresponding effect on MOF
structures when pursuing a PSM approach to form MMMs with desired
performance enhancements.

elements.content: The global demand for gas separations has been increasing, and membranes provide a promising alternative to conventional unit operations. In this regard, membranes potentially offer lower energy consumption, compact module size, and operational simplicity. However, conventional polymeric membranes experience a trade-off between permeability and selectivity, resulting in the establishment of so-called upper bounds that are based on the chemical and physical structure of the polymer.
elements.clean_text:
The global demand for gas separations
has been increasing, and membranes provide a promising alternative
to conventional unit operations. In this regard, membranes
potentially offer lower energy consumption, compact module size, and
operational simplicity. However, conventional
polymeric membranes experience a trade-off between permeability and
selectivity, resulting in the establishment of so-called upper bounds
that are based on the chemical and physical structure of the polymer.

elements.content: To surpass performance limitations of polymeric materials while still leveraging their processability and mechanical integrity, significant interest has focused on the development of mixed-matrix membranes (MMMs). MMMs are generally fabricated by dispersing fillers, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), zeolites, carbon molecular sieves, and other materials, into a polymeric matrix. Among the large number of potential filler materials, MOFs are some of the most frequently studied because of their high internal surface areas and accessible pore sizes that are sometimes desirable for size-screening in gas separations. The physical and chemical structures of MOFs can be easily manipulated to target specific separation challenges based on molecular size and affinity. However, in order to capture all of these perceived benefits, a key remaining challenge is to develop techniques to improve the interfacial compatibility between the MOF phase and the polymer to prevent the formation of interfacial defects, which lead to a significant loss in membrane selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
To surpass performance limitations of polymeric materials
while
still leveraging their processability and mechanical integrity, significant
interest has focused on the development of mixed-matrix membranes
(MMMs). MMMs are generally fabricated by dispersing
fillers, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), zeolites, carbon
molecular sieves, and other materials, into a polymeric matrix. Among the large number of potential filler
materials, MOFs are some of the most frequently studied because of
their high internal surface areas and accessible pore sizes that are
sometimes desirable for size-screening in gas separations. The physical and chemical structures of MOFs
can be easily manipulated to target specific separation challenges
based on molecular size and affinity. However, in order to capture
all of these perceived benefits, a key remaining challenge is to develop
techniques to improve the interfacial compatibility between the MOF
phase and the polymer to prevent the formation of interfacial defects,
which lead to a significant loss in membrane selectivity.

elements.content: To address the interfacial compatibility challenge, a variety of techniques have been developed, such as priming casting, thermal annealing, filler surface modification, filler morphology optimization, in situ synthesis of MOF particles, in situ polymerization, in situ modification of MOFs in the MMMs, and using ionic liquids (ILs) as interfacial agents. Among these techniques, MOF surface modification, especially post-synthetic modification (PSM), has been extensively studied, thus leading to what has been described as the “post-synthetic renaissance”.
elements.clean_text:
To address the interfacial compatibility
challenge, a variety of
techniques have been developed, such as priming casting, thermal annealing, filler surface modification, filler
morphology optimization,
in situ synthesis of MOF particles,
in situ polymerization,
in situ modification of MOFs in the MMMs, and using ionic liquids (ILs)
as interfacial agents. Among these techniques,
MOF surface modification, especially post-synthetic modification (PSM),
has been extensively studied, thus leading to what has been described
as the “post-synthetic renaissance”.

elements.content: Even though Robson and Hoskins predicted the concept of PSM for MOFs in 1990, one of the earliest experimental examples appeared almost 10 years later when Lee et al. conducted PSM reactions on MOFs via acetylation. Numerous studies have since appeared demonstrating a variety of covalent PSM techniques, includingamong many otherswork by the groups of Cohen, Yaghi, and Long.
elements.clean_text:
Even though Robson and Hoskins predicted the concept
of PSM for
MOFs in 1990, one of the earliest experimental
examples appeared almost 10 years later when Lee et al. conducted
PSM reactions on MOFs via acetylation. Numerous studies have since appeared demonstrating a variety of
covalent PSM techniques, includingamong many otherswork by the groups of Cohen, Yaghi, and Long.

elements.content: For membrane applications specifically, there are a variety of PSM studies on UiO-66-NH2. Vankelecom and co-workers modified UiO-66-NH2 with benzoic acid and 4-aminobenzoic acid via a modulated approach, aiming to enhance the separation performance of the MOF and improve particle–polyimide compatibility. Kaliaguine and co-workers demonstrated that a cross-linked MMM can be formed through in situ polymerization between PIM-1 and UiO-66-NH2 after modifying the MOF with one of the PIM monomers (i.e., 1,4-dicyanotetrafluorobenzene). Most of the above-mentioned examples involve chemical modifications to the MOF ligands throughout the entirety of the MOF pore structure since either monomers or other reactants are small enough to diffuse into the internal pores of the MOF. There are a variety of benefits to such approaches. In addition to simplified synthetic design, modifying the entire MOF lattice can provide extra affinity to corresponding guest molecules if strongly interacting functional groups are incorporated into the framework. However, depending on the MOF pore structure and final application target, the location and extent of these PSM reactions often need to be carefully controlled. For gas separation applications, size exclusion is often an important mechanism to enable selectivity. When MOF fillers are used in MMMs, precisely sized pore windows are generally targeted to enhance performance. Therefore, uncontrolled PSM to improve filler–matrix compatibility can subsequently lead to changes in the internal MOF pore structure or cause pore blockage. Moreover, because mathematical models are commonly employed to predict gas transport properties of pure filler particles in MMMs, if the internal physical and/or chemical structure of the MOF is altered through a PSM reaction, the application and, therefore, the predictive power of such models will intractably suffer.
elements.clean_text:
For membrane applications specifically,
there are a variety of
PSM studies on UiO-66-NH2. Vankelecom and co-workers modified
UiO-66-NH2 with benzoic acid and 4-aminobenzoic acid via
a modulated approach, aiming to enhance the separation performance
of the MOF and improve particle–polyimide compatibility. Kaliaguine and co-workers demonstrated that
a cross-linked MMM can be formed through in situ polymerization
between PIM-1 and UiO-66-NH2 after modifying the MOF with
one of the PIM monomers (i.e., 1,4-dicyanotetrafluorobenzene). Most of the above-mentioned examples involve
chemical modifications to the MOF ligands throughout the entirety
of the MOF pore structure since either monomers or other reactants
are small enough to diffuse into the internal pores of the MOF. There
are a variety of benefits to such approaches. In addition to simplified
synthetic design, modifying the entire MOF lattice can provide extra
affinity to corresponding guest molecules if strongly interacting
functional groups are incorporated into the framework. However, depending on the MOF pore structure
and final application target, the location and extent of these PSM
reactions often need to be carefully controlled. For gas separation
applications, size exclusion is often an important mechanism to enable
selectivity. When MOF fillers are used in MMMs, precisely sized pore
windows are generally targeted to enhance performance. Therefore,
uncontrolled PSM to improve filler–matrix compatibility can
subsequently lead to changes in the internal MOF pore structure or
cause pore blockage. Moreover, because mathematical
models are commonly employed to predict gas transport properties of
pure filler particles in MMMs, if the
internal physical and/or chemical structure of the MOF is altered
through a PSM reaction, the application and, therefore, the predictive
power of such models will intractably suffer.

elements.content: Due to the aforementioned challenges with the PSM approach, our group has designed a technique to control the PSM precursor size to achieve site-specific PSM only on the surface of a commonly studied MOF, UiO-66-NH2, while maintaining the internal pore structure. For this approach, a polyimide, 6FDA-Durene, which is synthesized from 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-phenylenediamine (Durene diamine) and 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­diphthalic anhydride (6FDA), was chosen as the matrix material. This polymer is frequently considered in the membrane literature, and it has excellent CO2/CH4 separation performance, which is known to match the polymer performance requirements that are needed to make high performance MMMs with other MOFs. Similar to the Durene diamine monomer, UiO-66-NH2 contains reactive amine groups, which should similarly cross-link with dianhydrides to form imide linkages. In order to complete the PSM reaction, 6FDA-Durene oligomers with dianhydride end groups were previously synthesized with a stoichiometric imbalance of monomers to form short imide oligomers with molecular weights of approximately 3700 g mol–1 (i.e., approximately 10 repeat units). Oligomers of this length are too large to enter the MOF pores, thereby retaining the internal porosity of UiO-66-NH2. Such an approach enables the surface modification of UiO-66-NH2 without disrupting the internal chemical and/or physical structure of UiO-66-NH2. In the current work, a different reaction route, chemical imidization, was pursued in addition to the previous thermal imidization route to study the impact of reaction pathways on the final structure and performance of PSM-MOF particles as fillers in MMMs.
elements.clean_text:
Due to the aforementioned
challenges with the PSM approach, our
group has designed a technique to control the PSM precursor size to
achieve site-specific PSM only on the surface of a commonly studied
MOF, UiO-66-NH2, while maintaining the internal pore structure. For this approach, a polyimide, 6FDA-Durene,
which is synthesized from 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-phenylenediamine
(Durene diamine) and 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)­diphthalic
anhydride (6FDA), was chosen as the matrix material. This polymer
is frequently considered in the membrane literature, and it has excellent CO2/CH4 separation
performance, which is known to match the polymer performance requirements
that are needed to make high performance MMMs with other MOFs. Similar to the Durene diamine monomer, UiO-66-NH2 contains
reactive amine groups, which should similarly cross-link with dianhydrides
to form imide linkages. In order to complete the PSM reaction, 6FDA-Durene
oligomers with dianhydride end groups were previously synthesized with a stoichiometric imbalance of monomers
to form short imide oligomers with molecular weights of approximately
3700 g mol–1 (i.e., approximately 10 repeat units).
Oligomers of this length are too large to enter the MOF pores, thereby
retaining the internal porosity of UiO-66-NH2. Such an
approach enables the surface modification of UiO-66-NH2 without disrupting the internal chemical and/or physical structure
of UiO-66-NH2. In the current work, a different reaction
route, chemical imidization, was pursued in addition to the previous
thermal imidization route to study the impact of reaction pathways
on the final structure and performance of PSM-MOF particles as fillers
in MMMs.

elements.content: Experimentally, as-synthesized UiO-66-NH2 was first suspended in a N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone solution that contained the dianhydride-end-capped 6FDA-Durene oligomer to form a poly­(amic acid) intermediate. Two common imidization routes were then used to convert the poly­(amic acid) linkage into a polyimide: (1) solution chemical imidization using pyridine and acetic anhydride and (2) solution thermal imidization using an unreactive azeotropic agent (i.e., 1,2-dichlorobenzene) and heat. Due to the different reactive species and procedures for each route, we expected to obtain PSM-MOF particles with slightly different chemical and/or physical properties. The UiO-66-NH2 MOF has two discrete pore aperture sizes of 6 and 9 Å, both of which are similar in size to that of the longest molecular end-to-end distance of acetic anhydride (7.92 Å). The chemical (C)-PSM procedure involves the addition of acetic anhydride as a dehydrating agent to remove water. However, acetic anhydride is also reactive toward the amino group on UiO-66-NH2, and since acetic anhydride is smaller than the large pore aperture of the MOF, it can react with both surface and internal amines. Conversely, the 6FDA-Durene oligomer is much larger than acetic anhydride and therefore less likely to penetrate the framework. We thus hypothesized that only surface reactions would occur with the oligomer for the thermal (T)-PSM route, but a combination of surface and internal reactions would occur with the C-PSM route. Furthermore, acetic anhydride will compete with the telechelic oligomer for surface −NH2 groups, which will affect the oligomer coverage on the MOF. A series of characterization techniques were applied to investigate this hypothesis, and a detailed discussion follows.
elements.clean_text:
Experimentally, as-synthesized UiO-66-NH2 was first
suspended in a N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone solution that
contained the dianhydride-end-capped 6FDA-Durene oligomer to form
a poly­(amic acid) intermediate. Two common imidization routes were
then used to convert the poly­(amic acid) linkage into a polyimide:
(1) solution chemical imidization using pyridine and acetic anhydride
and (2) solution thermal imidization using an unreactive azeotropic
agent (i.e., 1,2-dichlorobenzene) and heat. Due to the different reactive species and procedures for each route,
we expected to obtain PSM-MOF particles with slightly different chemical
and/or physical properties. The UiO-66-NH2 MOF has two
discrete pore aperture sizes of 6 and 9 Å, both of which are similar in size to that of the longest
molecular end-to-end distance of acetic anhydride (7.92 Å). The
chemical (C)-PSM procedure involves the addition of acetic anhydride
as a dehydrating agent to remove water. However, acetic anhydride
is also reactive toward the amino group on UiO-66-NH2, and since acetic anhydride is smaller than the
large pore aperture of the MOF, it can react with both surface and
internal amines. Conversely, the 6FDA-Durene oligomer is much larger
than acetic anhydride and therefore less likely to penetrate the framework.
We thus hypothesized that only surface reactions would occur with
the oligomer for the thermal (T)-PSM route, but a combination of surface
and internal reactions would occur with the C-PSM route. Furthermore,
acetic anhydride will compete with the telechelic oligomer for surface
−NH2 groups, which will affect the oligomer coverage
on the MOF. A series of characterization techniques were applied to
investigate this hypothesis, and a detailed discussion follows.

elements.content: The oligomer-coated MOF particles from the T-PSM and C-PSM routes appear somewhat similar under TEM analysis, as shown in , but their physical and chemical properties were altered in different ways. The T-PSM approach, which we have reported in our previous study, produced a MOF–oligomer core–shell structure with a regular coating layer of uniform thickness, whereas the C-PSM approach resulted in particles with a more irregular and rough surface. For the reaction, acetic anhydride was added with a concentration of reactive groups that was four times higher than that of the oligomer. Additionally, being a smaller molecule than the oligomer, acetic anhydride is expected to have a faster diffusion rate in the reaction solution. Because 6FDA-Durene oligomers and acetic anhydride compete for surface −NH2 groups on UiO-66-NH2, the aforementioned reaction considerations would result in a reduction of oligomer functionalization on the MOF surface, thus the observed irregular surface coverage.
elements.clean_text:
The oligomer-coated MOF particles from the T-PSM and C-PSM routes
appear somewhat similar under TEM analysis, as shown in , but their physical and chemical
properties were altered in different ways. The T-PSM approach, which
we have reported in our previous study, produced a MOF–oligomer core–shell structure with
a regular coating layer of uniform thickness, whereas the C-PSM approach
resulted in particles with a more irregular and rough surface. For
the reaction, acetic anhydride was added with a concentration of reactive
groups that was four times higher than that of the oligomer. Additionally,
being a smaller molecule than the oligomer, acetic anhydride is expected
to have a faster diffusion rate in the reaction solution. Because
6FDA-Durene oligomers and acetic anhydride compete for surface −NH2 groups on UiO-66-NH2, the aforementioned reaction
considerations would result in a reduction of oligomer functionalization
on the MOF surface, thus the observed irregular surface coverage.

elements.content: TEM images of (a) as-synthesized UiO-66-NH2, (b) T-PSM-MOF particles, and (c, d) C-PSM-MOF particles. Images in panels (a) and (b) have been reproduced from ref with permission.
elements.clean_text:
1

TEM images
of (a) as-synthesized UiO-66-NH2, (b) T-PSM-MOF
particles, and (c, d) C-PSM-MOF particles. Images in panels (a) and
(b) have been reproduced from ref with permission.

elements.content: d and Figure S1 also show some apparent amorphous contribution to the C-PSM-MOF structures. There are two possibilities to explain these findings. First, slightly different molecular lengths were used for the two surface modifiers. The T-PSM oligomer had a number-average molecular weight of 3700 g mol–1, and the C-PSM oligomer had a number-average molecular weight of 8700 g mol–1. The larger oligomers used in the C-PSM reaction would result in a larger amorphous contribution as observed in the TEM image. Second, UiO-66-type MOFs are known to have some degradation issues when they are not in a neutral solution. The amorphous regions observed in d and Figure S1 could therefore relate to MOF degradation for the C-PSM reaction. There is literature evidence that UiO-66-NH2 is stable in the presence of acetic anhydride, and since our telechelic oligomers contain a chemically similar dianhydride reactive group, it is most likely that any framework degradation would be attributed to the use of pyridine in the C-PSM reaction. Of note, the samples were thoroughly washed with NMP following the PSM reaction, which, given the solubility of the polymer in this solvent, should result in the removal of unreacted oligomer from the particles. For these reasons, the observed amorphous contributions from the C-PSM reaction likely result from the use of longer oligomers and the use of pyridine in the C-PSM reaction. This amorphous structure would, of course, need to be chemically tethered to a UiO-66-NH2 particle to prevent its removal from the PSM-MOF particle suspension. Therefore, these amorphous structures should not be unreacted small molecules or dissociated ligands.
elements.clean_text:
d and Figure S1 also show some apparent amorphous contribution
to the C-PSM-MOF structures. There are two possibilities to explain
these findings. First, slightly different molecular lengths were used
for the two surface modifiers. The T-PSM oligomer had a number-average
molecular weight of 3700 g mol–1, and the C-PSM
oligomer had a number-average molecular weight of 8700 g mol–1. The larger oligomers used in the C-PSM reaction would result in
a larger amorphous contribution as observed in the TEM image. Second,
UiO-66-type MOFs are known to have some degradation issues when they
are not in a neutral solution. The amorphous
regions observed in d and Figure S1 could therefore
relate to MOF degradation for the C-PSM reaction. There is literature
evidence that UiO-66-NH2 is stable in the presence of acetic
anhydride, and since our telechelic oligomers
contain a chemically similar dianhydride reactive group, it is most
likely that any framework degradation would be attributed to the use
of pyridine in the C-PSM reaction. Of
note, the samples were thoroughly washed with NMP following the PSM
reaction, which, given the solubility of the polymer in this solvent,
should result in the removal of unreacted oligomer from the particles.
For these reasons, the observed amorphous contributions from the C-PSM
reaction likely result from the use of longer oligomers and the use
of pyridine in the C-PSM reaction. This amorphous structure would,
of course, need to be chemically tethered to a UiO-66-NH2 particle to prevent its removal from the PSM-MOF particle suspension.
Therefore, these amorphous structures should not be unreacted small
molecules or dissociated ligands.

elements.content: A variety of characterization techniques were used to evaluate oligomer coverage on the MOF surface. TEM-EDX and FTIR results, presented in a and Figure S2, respectively, confirm the presence of polymer on the PSM-MOF particles. Elemental analysis indicates fluorine functionality on the PSM-MOF particles, which is expected due to the fluorine functionality that is present in the polymer but absent from the pure MOF. FTIR results offer a similar interpretation. After both the C- and T-PSM reaction, a decrease in intensity is observed for the ν (−NH2) band centered at 3490 cm–1. This diminishing intensity corresponds with the appearance of new bands for ν (−Ar–CO) centered at 1700 cm–1, indicating the conversion of −NH2 groups on the MOF to polyimide linkages. The T-PSM route resulted in a more prominent ν (−Ar–CO) peak, suggesting higher oligomer coverage than that of the C-PSM route. By contrast, TGA and XRD, presented in b and c, respectively, suggest that the two reaction routes produced particles with some distinct characteristics. First, the extent of mass loss between 250 and 400 °C for the C-PSM-MOF relative to the T-PSM-MOF is suppressed, supporting our above assertion that the oligomer coverage was reduced when the PSM reaction occurred in the presence of acetic anhydride. Second, relative intensities of the XRD patterns indicate a higher degree of retained crystallinity for the T-PSM-MOF relative to that of the C-PSM-MOF. These findings support our earlier claims of potential MOF degradation that can occur when pyridine is used in the PSM reaction.

A variety of characterization
techniques were used to evaluate
oligomer coverage on the MOF surface. TEM-EDX and FTIR results, presented
in a and Figure S2, respectively, confirm the presence
of polymer on the PSM-MOF particles. Elemental analysis indicates
fluorine functionality on the PSM-MOF particles, which is expected
due to the fluorine functionality that is present in the polymer but
absent from the pure MOF. FTIR results offer a similar interpretation.
After both the C- and T-PSM reaction, a decrease in intensity is observed
for the ν (−NH2) band centered at 3490 cm–1. This diminishing intensity corresponds with the
appearance of new bands for ν (−Ar–CO)
centered at 1700 cm–1, indicating the conversion
of −NH2 groups on the MOF to polyimide linkages.
The T-PSM route resulted in a more prominent ν (−Ar–CO)
peak, suggesting higher oligomer coverage than that of the C-PSM route.
By contrast, TGA and XRD, presented in b and c, respectively, suggest that the two
reaction routes produced particles with some distinct characteristics.
First, the extent of mass loss between 250 and 400 °C for the C-PSM-MOF
relative to the T-PSM-MOF is suppressed, supporting our above
assertion that the oligomer coverage was reduced when the PSM reaction
occurred in the presence of acetic anhydride. Second, relative intensities
of the XRD patterns indicate a higher degree of retained crystallinity
for the T-PSM-MOF relative to that of the C-PSM-MOF. These
findings support our earlier claims of potential MOF degradation that
can occur when pyridine is used in the PSM reaction.

elements.content: (a) TEM-EDX, (b) TGA, and (c) XRD results for Pure MOF, C-PSM-MOF, and T-PSM-MOF. The TGA plot also includes the oligomer curve for reference.
elements.clean_text:
2

(a) TEM-EDX, (b) TGA,
and (c) XRD results for Pure MOF, C-PSM-MOF,
and T-PSM-MOF. The TGA plot also includes the oligomer curve for reference.

elements.content: BET surface area was measured to study the impact of synthesis routes on the MOF structure. Following the T-PSM reaction, there was a decrease in BET surface area from 980 to 750 m2 g–1, as illustrated in a. The contribution from the nonporous 6FDA-Durene oligomer coating was the major cause for this reduction in gravimetric surface area. If we assume the T-PSM-MOF particles are perfect spheres with diameters of 50 nm and uniform 5 nm oligomer coatings, as estimated from TEM, the polymer shells would account for approximately 29% of the total mass of the T-PSM-MOF (cf., SI Section 3.1), ignoring any effect from pore blocking or an internal reaction. Given these assumptions, the expected surface areas of T-PSM-MOF particles would be approximately 700 m2 g–1, which is remarkably close to our measured BET surface areas. This similarity supports our previous assertion that the T-PSM-MOF has an unblocked and unreacted UiO-66-NH2 core, making it an ideal system for studying and predicting transport properties in MMMs. In contrast, the BET surface area decreased significantly to 250 m2 g–1 after the C-PSM reaction. This decrease in internal surface area likely relates to a reduction in accessible pore volume as a result of the internal amine–acetic anhydride reaction. In addition, it is also possible that longer oligomer chains used in the C-PSM route could result in increased pore blocking effects, further reducing the surface area. Moreover, the decreased crystalline intensity from XRD in c and the observed amorphous features from TEM analysis in Figure S1 indicate that structural degradation likely contributes to this decrease in surface area as well.

BET surface area was measured to study the impact
of synthesis
routes on the MOF structure. Following the T-PSM reaction, there was
a decrease in BET surface area from 980 to 750 m2 g–1, as illustrated in a. The contribution from the nonporous 6FDA-Durene
oligomer coating was the major cause for this reduction in gravimetric
surface area. If we assume the T-PSM-MOF
particles are perfect spheres with diameters of 50 nm and uniform
5 nm oligomer coatings, as estimated from TEM, the polymer shells
would account for approximately 29% of the total mass of the T-PSM-MOF
(cf., SI Section 3.1), ignoring any effect
from pore blocking or an internal reaction. Given these assumptions,
the expected surface areas of T-PSM-MOF particles would be approximately
700 m2 g–1, which is remarkably close
to our measured BET surface areas. This similarity supports our previous
assertion that the T-PSM-MOF has an unblocked and unreacted UiO-66-NH2 core, making it an ideal system for studying and predicting
transport properties in MMMs. In contrast, the BET surface area decreased
significantly to 250 m2 g–1 after the
C-PSM reaction. This decrease in internal surface area likely relates
to a reduction in accessible pore volume as a result of the internal
amine–acetic anhydride reaction. In addition, it is also possible that longer oligomer chains used
in the C-PSM route could result in increased pore blocking effects,
further reducing the surface area. Moreover, the decreased crystalline
intensity from XRD in c and the observed amorphous features from TEM analysis in Figure S1 indicate that structural degradation
likely contributes to this decrease in surface area as well.

elements.content: (a) N2 adsorption isotherms at 77K and (b) pore distribution based on DFT calculations for the Pure MOF, T-PSM-MOF, and C-PSM-MOF. BET surface areas for the three particles are 980, 750, and 250 m2 g–1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
3

(a) N2 adsorption isotherms at 77K and (b) pore distribution
based on DFT calculations for the Pure MOF, T-PSM-MOF, and C-PSM-MOF.
BET surface areas for the three particles are 980, 750, and 250 m2 g–1, respectively.

elements.content: Within the framework of the sorption–diffusion model, the reduction in BET surface area for the C-PSM-MOF is expected to significantly reduce permeability when the particles are incorporated into MMMs. In terms of sorption, fewer sorption sites will be present, and in terms of diffusion, a constriction of the pore channels within the MOF lattice will result from internal reactions. Both of these effects would reduce permeability. Pore size distribution analysis in b confirms this interpretation. Ideally, UiO-66-NH2 only contains pores of 6 and 9 Å with 12 complete ligand molecules connected to each metal cluster. However, by introducing modulators such as acetic acid during synthesis to control nanoparticle size, missing linker defects can result. As a consequence, the distribution of larger pores between approximately 12 and 20 Å that we observed in our samples are likely a result of some concentration of expected defect sites in UiO-66-NH2. After the T-PSM reaction in our study, analysis of the pore width of the smaller UiO-66-NH2 cavities did not reveal a significant change, while the effective pore volume decreased slightly, a result that is consistent with the added mass from the nonporous oligomer coating. However, the pore width of the larger UiO-66-NH2 defect cavities shows a slight decrease in average pore width, which may suggest the oligomer chains protrude to a limited extent into some of these larger defect pores. For the C-PSM-MOF, there is a significant decrease in the pore volume for the smaller cavities and a complete loss of pore volume for the larger defect cavities, which has been observed in similar UiO-66 modification experiments reported elsewhere. These observations suggest that acetic anhydride molecules diffuse into the MOF internal porosity and react with the internal amino groups, completely blocking the larger defect cavities. Therefore, synthetic approaches that do not require small reactive molecules, such as the T-PSM approach, are required to form UiO-66-NH2 without significant modification to the internal pore.
elements.clean_text:
Within the framework of the sorption–diffusion model, the reduction in BET surface area for the C-PSM-MOF
is expected to significantly reduce permeability when the particles
are incorporated into MMMs. In terms of sorption, fewer sorption sites
will be present, and in terms of diffusion, a constriction of the
pore channels within the MOF lattice will result from internal reactions.
Both of these effects would reduce permeability. Pore size distribution
analysis in b confirms this interpretation. Ideally, UiO-66-NH2 only
contains pores of 6 and 9 Å with 12 complete ligand molecules
connected to each metal cluster. However, by introducing modulators
such as acetic acid during synthesis to control nanoparticle size,
missing linker defects can result. As
a consequence, the distribution of larger pores between approximately
12 and 20 Å that we observed in our samples are likely a result
of some concentration of expected defect sites in UiO-66-NH2. After the T-PSM reaction in our study, analysis of the pore width
of the smaller UiO-66-NH2 cavities did not reveal a significant
change, while the effective pore volume decreased slightly, a result
that is consistent with the added mass from the nonporous oligomer
coating. However, the pore width of the larger UiO-66-NH2 defect cavities shows a slight decrease in average pore width, which
may suggest the oligomer chains protrude to a limited extent into
some of these larger defect pores. For the C-PSM-MOF, there is a significant
decrease in the pore volume for the smaller cavities and a complete
loss of pore volume for the larger defect cavities, which has been
observed in similar UiO-66 modification experiments reported elsewhere. These observations suggest that acetic anhydride
molecules diffuse into the MOF internal porosity and react with the
internal amino groups, completely blocking the larger defect cavities.
Therefore, synthetic approaches that do not require small reactive
molecules, such as the T-PSM approach, are required to form UiO-66-NH2 without significant modification to the internal pore.

elements.content: Ideal (i.e., pure gas) permeabilities for CO2 and CH4 were determined for a series of MMM samples by incorporating different loadings of the T/C-PSM-MOF particles into high molecular weight 6FDA-Durene polymers. These data are summarized on an upper bound plot in and tabulated in Tables S1 and S2. With increased loadings of T-PSM-MOF, a synergistic improvement in both CO2 permeability and CO2/CH4 selectivity was observed, owing to the improved interfacial compatibility provided by the oligomer coating. Conversely, a significant decrease in permeability and an increase in selectivity was observed for MMMs containing the C-PSM-MOF particles. Pore blockage due to acetic anhydride reactions with the internal amines in the MOF increases the tortuosity inside the MOF while simultaneously decreasing the accumulated pore volume. Both effects will result in reduced diffusion and lower sorption of gas molecules inside the MOF. Methane has a larger kinetic diameter than CO2 and was therefore more significantly affected by the C-PSM route, which led to a higher CO2/CH4 selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Ideal (i.e., pure gas) permeabilities for CO2 and CH4 were determined for a series of MMM samples by incorporating
different loadings of the T/C-PSM-MOF particles into high molecular
weight 6FDA-Durene polymers. These data are summarized on an upper
bound plot in  and tabulated in Tables S1 and S2. With
increased loadings of T-PSM-MOF, a synergistic improvement in both
CO2 permeability and CO2/CH4 selectivity
was observed, owing to the improved interfacial compatibility provided
by the oligomer coating. Conversely,
a significant decrease in permeability and an increase in selectivity
was observed for MMMs containing the C-PSM-MOF particles. Pore blockage
due to acetic anhydride reactions with the internal amines in the
MOF increases the tortuosity inside the MOF while simultaneously decreasing
the accumulated pore volume. Both effects will result in reduced diffusion
and lower sorption of gas molecules inside the MOF. Methane has a
larger kinetic diameter than CO2 and was therefore more
significantly affected by the C-PSM route, which led to a higher CO2/CH4 selectivity.

elements.content: CO2/CH4 upper bound plot for 6FDA-Durene (black), T-PSM-MOF MMMs (red), and C-PSM-MOF MMMs (blue). Exact loadings are presented in Tables S1 and S2. Results are for pure-gas permeation tests conducted at 1 bar and 35 °C.
elements.clean_text:
4

CO2/CH4 upper bound plot for 6FDA-Durene
(black), T-PSM-MOF MMMs (red), and C-PSM-MOF MMMs (blue). Exact loadings
are presented in Tables S1 and S2. Results
are for pure-gas permeation tests conducted at 1 bar and 35 °C.

elements.content: Time-lag estimates of diffusivity were inaccessible due to the extremely short time lag for CO2. Therefore, sorption tests for various samples were conducted to determine sorption and calculate diffusivity via the sorption–diffusion model. Sorption isotherms are summarized in Figure S3. A very clear trend can be observed that the addition of C-PSM-MOFs lowered CO2 and CH4 sorption, whereas the addition of T-PSM-MOFs increased gas sorption in the MMMs. The significant change in gas sorption correlates systematically with reductions in CO2 permeability for the C-PSM-MOF MMMs. Furthermore, the addition of both T- and C-PSM-MOFs slightly increased sorption selectivity; however, a slightly larger increase in sorption selectivity was observed for the C-PSM-MOF MMMs. Although more free amines are present in the T-PSM-MOF particles, which are known to preferentially interact with CO2, the reduction in accessible pore volume likely results in a size screening effect, whereby CH4 is more readily excluded compared to CO2 from the C-PSM-MOF framework due to its larger size. As a result, the higher CO2/CH4 sorption selectivity of 3.2 for the 15 wt % T-PSM-MOF MMM at 1 bar contributed to the higher overall selectivity in the T-PSM-MOF MMMs relative to the pristine 6FDA-Durene film, which has a CO2/CH4 sorption selectivity of 3.0 under the same conditions. Moreover, an even higher CO2/CH4 sorption selectivity of 3.4 for 15 wt % C-PSM-MOF MMM at 1 bar resulted in a further increase in selectivity for C-PSM-MOF MMMs compared to the other samples. Due to the size screening effect mentioned above, a higher CO2/CH4 diffusion selectivity of 5.4 was observed for the 15% C-PSM-MOF MMM as compared to a CO2/CH4 diffusion selectivity of 5.1 for the T-PSM-MOF MMM, thus explaining the higher overall selectivity in the C-PSM-MOF MMM.
elements.clean_text:
Time-lag estimates of diffusivity were inaccessible
due to the
extremely short time lag for CO2. Therefore, sorption tests
for various samples were conducted to determine sorption and calculate
diffusivity via the sorption–diffusion model. Sorption isotherms
are summarized in Figure S3. A very clear
trend can be observed that the addition of C-PSM-MOFs lowered CO2 and CH4 sorption, whereas the addition of T-PSM-MOFs
increased gas sorption in the MMMs. The significant change in gas
sorption correlates systematically with reductions in CO2 permeability for the C-PSM-MOF MMMs. Furthermore, the addition of
both T- and C-PSM-MOFs slightly increased sorption selectivity; however,
a slightly larger increase in sorption selectivity was observed for
the C-PSM-MOF MMMs. Although more free amines are present in the T-PSM-MOF
particles, which are known to preferentially interact with CO2, the reduction in accessible pore volume
likely results in a size screening effect, whereby CH4 is
more readily excluded compared to CO2 from the C-PSM-MOF
framework due to its larger size. As
a result, the higher CO2/CH4 sorption selectivity
of 3.2 for the 15 wt % T-PSM-MOF MMM at 1 bar contributed to the higher
overall selectivity in the T-PSM-MOF MMMs relative to the pristine
6FDA-Durene film, which has a CO2/CH4 sorption
selectivity of 3.0 under the same conditions. Moreover, an even higher
CO2/CH4 sorption selectivity of 3.4 for 15 wt
% C-PSM-MOF MMM at 1 bar resulted in a further increase in selectivity
for C-PSM-MOF MMMs compared to the other samples. Due to the
size screening effect mentioned above, a higher CO2/CH4 diffusion selectivity of 5.4 was observed for the 15%
C-PSM-MOF MMM as compared to a CO2/CH4 diffusion
selectivity of 5.1 for the T-PSM-MOF MMM, thus explaining the higher
overall selectivity in the C-PSM-MOF MMM.

elements.content: At 30 wt % loading of C-PSM-MOF, the CO2/CH4 selectivity increased to 30, resulting in property sets that were near the 2008 upper bound. However, the permeability decreased by 54% to 590 Barrer when compared to the pure polymer. Owing to the nearly perfect interfacial interaction in the T-PSM-MOF MMMs, the Maxwell model has been successfully applied with good experimental agreement to predict transport properties for this pure MOF. However, for the C-PSM-MOF MMMs, the alteration of the MOF internal pore structure and the possible introduction of defects by degradation under basic conditions precludes the ability to estimate pure MOF transport properties with the Maxwell model. Therefore, the use and application of the Maxwell model for MMMs formed with PSM particles requires the careful design of experimental conditions needed to preserve the MOF structure. Failure to do so does not prevent the formation of composites with an ideal polymer–particle interface, but it does preclude the ability to use theoretical models to derive transport properties of the unmodified particle fillers.
elements.clean_text:
At 30 wt % loading
of C-PSM-MOF, the CO2/CH4 selectivity increased
to 30, resulting in property sets that were
near the 2008 upper bound. However, the
permeability decreased by 54% to 590 Barrer when compared to the pure
polymer. Owing to the nearly perfect interfacial interaction in the
T-PSM-MOF MMMs, the Maxwell model has been successfully applied with
good experimental agreement to predict transport properties for this
pure MOF. However, for the C-PSM-MOF
MMMs, the alteration of the MOF internal pore structure and the possible
introduction of defects by degradation under basic conditions precludes
the ability to estimate pure MOF transport properties with the Maxwell
model. Therefore, the use and application of the Maxwell model for
MMMs formed with PSM particles requires the careful design of experimental
conditions needed to preserve the MOF structure. Failure to do so
does not prevent the formation of composites with an ideal polymer–particle
interface, but it does preclude the ability to use theoretical models
to derive transport properties of the unmodified particle fillers.

elements.content: In summary, we have used two different reaction pathways (T-PSM and C-PSM) to functionalize UiO-66-NH2 with 6FDA-Durene oligomers via imidization reactions. Modified fillers were then incorporated into 6FDA-Durene polymers to prepare MMMs with different loadings. Characterization tests revealed that the T-PSM approach resulted in a reaction that was predominately on the surface of the MOF. Therefore, when dispersing T-PSM-MOF particles into MMMs, improvements were observed in both permeability and selectivity due to desired interfacial compatibility and access to the unmodified pore chemistry and structure of UiO-66-NH2. Furthermore, the Maxwell model can be applied to predict transport properties in pure UiO-66-NH2 when using the T-PSM approach. Conversely, the C-PSM approach resulted in reactions on the MOF surface and in the internal MOF pores as a result of using acetic anhydride and pyridine. The internal reactions reduced sorption and diffusion and led to a decrease in permeability with an increase in selectivity in the corresponding MMMs. Furthermore, compared to the T-PSM approach, the C-PSM approach resulted in a rougher MOF surface due to reduced oligomer coverage and a decrease in crystallinity due to the required reaction conditions. This study illustrates the importance of selecting PSM conditions that preserve the MOF structure of interest. Doing so enables the formation of MMMs that can be prepared for the successful application of predictive models needed to assess separation performance of the fillers.
elements.clean_text:
In summary, we have used two different reaction pathways (T-PSM
and C-PSM) to functionalize UiO-66-NH2 with 6FDA-Durene
oligomers via imidization reactions. Modified fillers were then incorporated
into 6FDA-Durene polymers to prepare MMMs with different loadings.
Characterization tests revealed that the T-PSM approach resulted in
a reaction that was predominately on the surface of the MOF. Therefore,
when dispersing T-PSM-MOF particles into MMMs, improvements were observed
in both permeability and selectivity due to desired interfacial compatibility
and access to the unmodified pore chemistry and structure of UiO-66-NH2. Furthermore, the Maxwell model can be applied to predict
transport properties in pure UiO-66-NH2 when using the
T-PSM approach. Conversely, the C-PSM approach resulted in reactions
on the MOF surface and in the internal MOF pores as a result of using
acetic anhydride and pyridine. The internal reactions reduced sorption
and diffusion and led to a decrease in permeability with an increase
in selectivity in the corresponding MMMs. Furthermore, compared to
the T-PSM approach, the C-PSM approach resulted in a rougher MOF surface
due to reduced oligomer coverage and a decrease in crystallinity due
to the required reaction conditions. This study illustrates the importance
of selecting PSM conditions that preserve the MOF structure of interest.
Doing so enables the formation of MMMs that can be prepared for the
successful application of predictive models needed to assess separation
performance of the fillers.

metadata.title:
Impact of Post-Synthetic Modification Routes on Filler
Structure and Performance in Metal–Organic Framework-Based
Mixed-Matrix Membranes
